messageBody:
Back from work... let's continue the thread.....


On 6/11/02 7:59 AM, "Luca Sfarzo" <luca.sfarzo@...> wrote:

> Hi think that using a mediator could guarantee you from separating the
> mechanism for handling data that lies deep in the "core" of your application
> from the GUI details, but sometimes the behavior of a single form can be
> driven by a many-state state machine (so being very complex) and some
> transitions should rely on some other data liyng somewhere else in the depth
> of the application.


I pushed on Mediator a little too hard this morning. The purpose of a
Mediator is to decouple individual controls from each other. We're talking
about a class that does more than that, we're talking about a class that
sits between the domain knowledge and the gui. I call such a class a
Presenter, after the Model-View-Presenter architecture. Martin Fowler calls
this an Application Fa√ßade. Whatever you call it, it knows how to get what
it needs from the Model and it knows how to drive the gui. With that out of
the way, let's get specific.


> Here the problem arises.
>
> One example should be if I would test my GUI behavior when something
> somewhere else changes.
>
> I.e. I'm editing some fields to be sent later to a server and the connection
> goes down. Ok the mediator can do the great part of the job but what if my
> current form should let me save the data into a file in order to retrieve
> them later? That kind of knowledge lies inside the form (it's its own
> responsibility, above all!) while the constraints come from the outer world.
>

Well, you certainly COULD put the knowledge in the gui, but now we're back
to having to test it and worrying about how to test it and maintain it - a
job that you're probably finding out is very difficult.

What if the Form gathers the information like it always does and sends it in
the form of a message to the Presenter, which checks for a good db
connection and decides what to do? I'm back to a Presenter which is easy to
unit test and a gui that's dumber than dirt.
